comments.commentBody:
The second rule of science: Mistakes are more common than Miracles.

It follows that when ever you think a miracle may have occurred, it is almost always because there has been a mistake somewhere in the sequence of events. That it has not yet been detected is not proof that it does not exist.

Fair enough Raymond.

I alway revert to tested and proven US model though.

If California has special needs, they issue California debt denominated in USD, as does Mississippi.

So I don't see the need for multiple currencies.

I think you and I are trying to address the same thing: stimulating one region and moderating another due to relative performance.

A common currency is not an impediment given flexible member-state budgets, missing in the formation of the European Union.

In fact, they did the opposite: rigid member-state budgets with penalties for failures.

This puts member-state economies in straight-jackets: Greece was only able to deflate prices in a crisis in order to revive the economy, increasing the value of indebtedness.

With Brexit, optimal time for the EU to launch their own self-financed Marshall plan.

Take all the debt purchased by ECB and replaced with euros and transform it to Eurobonds backed by the ECB.

Banks need HQLA for Basel III.

This permanently reduces debt service costs for any monetary policy.

It de-risks banks and works by leaving all member-states with 10% of former sovereign debt to finance out of direct member-state taxation.

This provides money to address 20%+ unemployment and other structural impediments to growth and prosperity.

Imagine all the money spent freely on war during Europe's history.

Compare that to the imaginary cost of transforming debt held by the ECB already when deflation is the concern de jour.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
Bruce - the ending was the part you apparently missed.

''Why should my inability to offer an explanation trump her belief? However they are interpreted, miracles exist, because that is how they are lived in our world.''
Many of us tried being our own god and decided that we couldn't handle the responsibilities.
To the progressive, reality is a manufactured definition.

BR,

And what if a Miracle does not make you feel better ?

The human mind seeks what I call, "definitions of reality". (I'm putting on my philosopher hat). The mind seeks stability, that is, it tries to create a reference framework which reduces anxiety. Without that baseline reference, we are unable to distinguish reality from fantasy. This is necessary because we are capable fantasizing. Not being able to make this distinction creates enormous anxiety, which the mind seeks to avoid. It's like mental pain.

This is a natural response to the problem of consciousness, of self awareness. Much of what we are aware of is unexplainable. We then manufacture these definitions which is done in response to the need to reduce anxiety.

That's where miracles come from. That's where the universal human need for religion comes from. Even to say that there is no reason for these occurrences, that they are purely random events, is an anxiety reducing mechanism.

So that's it. The miracle response happens to make us feel better. How we get form here to there is where religion and science occupy the same space.

and Elke
Tristan- Awww- that ITTY bitty OTTER is sooo cute. Thanks for sharing.
I knew we were getting a an otter picture today (and why not).

He's adorable. (Has there ever been an OTTER that's not?)

According to the article, if little Rialto survives he'll most likely be moving to Vancouver.

Yesterday the giant panda was removed from the Endangered Species list! What wonderful news!

Alas, the Grauer's gorilla, the world's largest ape, was added to the list.

Timothy, you can't quit. You brought us OTTERS. Thank you and nice puzzle.

A very cute and very fluffy stranded sea otter pup is being rehabilitated by the Seattle Aquarium.
http://blog.seattleaquarium.org/conservation/sea-otter-pup/
Otter cam: http://www.seattleaquarium.org/otter-cam

One of the NFL's most disgusting blind-eye act is for referees to ignore the players who frequently lead with their helmet for hits against the opposing team's quarter-back. Those players ought to be suspended from the game. Secondly, another disgusting act is for the NFL owners to continue ignoring scientific evidence that hard-hits to the head frequently cause concussions with debilitating brain damage. It is truly pathetic for the NFL commissioner to receive a monstrous salary and owners to become extremely rich - when older players are poor and incapacitated due to brain injuries from their many years of playing football. Hopefully we will see the end of football within our generation.
I'm not a tennis fan, but if I know Venus is on TV I watch the match.  She's very special.

I fully support needle exchanges, but we also need a place to dispose of them.  Living in a city, I occasionally find needles.  Yet trying to find a proper way to dispose of them can be a challenge. So yes, give people clean needles, but also give them a proper place to dispose of them.

As an HIV doctor, I know that measures to reduce the likelihood of HIV transmission (there are now 40,000 new cases each year in the US) are a very good investment. EVERY CASE is preventable!

Just as many intravenous drug users are not concerned primarily about lowering their risk of infection with bloodborne pathogens, they are not likely to maintain their habit merely because someone gives them a clean needle. I have never heard of a habit prolonged due to a clean needle. The drive to use heroin is so strong that they will use it whether the needle available to them is used or new. And dirty needles are available.

HIV is a chronic disease and many people still die from it; I have known dozens of people who have lost their lives to AIDS. Children are still born with HIV. Treating it is not a trivial matter, and less than 1/3 of all US patents are treated adequately. The balance of evidence -- ethically, financially, and logically -- clearly and convincingly calls for an expansion of needle exchange programs. To do otherwise is to be working on the wrong side -- the side of HIV and AIDS -- in our battle with this killer virus.

"NEPs may encourage drug use and increase the number of dirty needles."
SteveRR, ah, no, that's not what happens as numerous studies have shown.
Politics are not 'tricky'. Politicians are cowardly, not interested in doing what is best for society and their constituents, but doing what is best for their own image.
Because we live in a compassionate society that takes care of those who need it.  I'll bet you go to church too...
Martin, Phyllis couldn't stand the thought of HRE being the next President. My guy couldn't either, so I went male over female, if for no other reason than to please Leapy. I am here to please.

Dear Raymond,

I should clarify one important thing: transforming all public and private debt holdings presently held by the ECB into Eurobonds backed by the ECB will, of course, impact the value of the euro.

The good news, the euro can be depreciated without negative nominal rates that distort capital asset prices, misallocate resources, and increase capital market instability.

It effectively de-risks not just the banking system but global capital markets as well.

Please pass this on to friends at ECB. I have a bit of background in this.

Redneck:"The term characterized farmers having a red neck caused by sunburn from hours working in the fields. A citation from 1893 provides a definition as "poorer inhabitants of the rural districts...men who work in the field, as a matter of course, generally have their skin stained red and burnt by the sun, and especially is this true of the back of their necks" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redneck
Thank you David Parsons.  It's too easy to just throw the Monopoly board into the air when you're losing, as if you're a child who learned a little in school and thinks now that the game is rigged.
The first one I probably bought as a 45 was "Guantanamera" by the Sandpipers, a Top 10 hit in 1966.  Sung in Spanish, with a bit of English narration on top.

One more. I remember this being around the same time as The Singing Nun. Sukiyaki:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C35DrtPlUbc

Pretty song with a completely invented American title. La Bamba was still a few years earlier.
Tragically, Kyu Sakamoto, the singer of "Sukiyaki," died in the crash of a Japanese Airlines 747 in 1985, one of 520 people who perished.
Doris Day got all global music back in the day with QUE SERA SERA, if I'm not mistaken.  What's the first "foreign language" pop song you ever heard?  Carlos Santana? The Singing Nun?

and Elke

Actually Harry Reid, a Democrat, stopped that bill by tying other provisions to the bill.
(Not Mark) You're misinformed, it was Harry Reid that stopped that bill.

Republicans are not only impervious to science, they're actively hostile to it.  The GOP is a cult with its own saints (chiefly Ronald Reagan) and its own inviolable dogmas.  For all the wreckage he is creating in the GOP, even Trump is doing nothing to alter the Republican hostility to scientific evidence.   Global warming, HPV vaccination, etc -- they're all conspiracies to America's new Know Nothing party.

Tristan- Awww- that ITTY bitty OTTER is sooo cute. Thanks for sharing.

A three-word phrase doesn't make for a foreign language song. QUE SERÁ, SERÁ is usually cited as Spanish, but as a stretch it could be French and sounds a lot like the Italian CHE SARÀ, SARÀ. José Feliciano recorded a different song in Spanish titled QUE SERÁ. He also recorded an Italian version CHE SARÀ. Those were both definitely foreign language songs to me.

https://youtu.be/sb1_b8y5XZ0
It's alarming how quickly the phrases of resignation came to me. Oh, well.  What are ya gonna do?
